Title: Prem: My mother was a big inspiration for my films, especially Jogi
Content: ‚ÄúThis is where she was at her happiest. So, I‚Äôve dedicated this space to her and called it Ammana Thota . It‚Äôs a befitting tribute to a woman who gave her everything to me until her last day,‚Äù says a wistful Prem. The director who lost his mother recently to cancer, is in his hometown Maddur for the post death rites along with his family.‚ÄúMy mother got married rather early and dedicated her life in raising her three kids amid poverty. Not once did she complain about her life and always lived it within modest means. Even when I made it big in films, she continued being the simple villager that she is,‚Äù shares Prem.The mother sentiment has always been a major element in Prem‚Äôs films, which he attributes to being inspired by his mom. ‚ÄúMy mother was the biggest inspiration for Jogi . Her name was Bhagyamma , which is what Arundhati Nag ‚Äôs character was called in the film. Every scene between her and Shivarajkumar was how my mother behaved with me in real life. She was the most selfless woman I‚Äôve ever met,‚Äù states the director-actor.Three years ago, Bhagyamma was diagnosed with cancer, and although she was responding well to the treatment and seemed on the path to recovery, she had a relapse a few months ago. ‚ÄúSuch was her blind love and innocence for me that when the doctor told her that she had breast cancer and asked her if they could go ahead with the surgery, she told them that she would do whatever her son says. She always shied away from media attention and wanted to return to our village and live there. She has been living with me and dedicating this thota to her is my tribute to my mother,‚Äù says Prem, who vowed to dedicate all his future films to his late mother. ‚ÄúMy wife and siblings are helping me recoup from this loss and I have now decided to set up a trust in her name to help lesser privileged people with their medical needs,‚Äù he signs off.

Title: This Indian jewellery designer worked on the world's most expensive dress
Content: They say India is a treasure trove of talent, and Indian designers, artists and performers have proved the same time and again. Indian jewellery designer, Kusum Jain, behind the popular jewellery brand K Jewels did the country proud as she contributed in the making of world's most expensive dress. Yes, you read that right!UK based designer, Josh Birchjones behind the 'Designed by Josh' set a record of sorts last year as he showcased his creations at the coveted London Fashion Week at the tender age of 14 years. And, when Josh needed help in designing world's most famous dress, he looked at Kusum for help.Josh designed his finale dress which was eventually worn by late Charlie Chaplin's daughter, Kiera Chaplin and was worth 50 million British pounds. And, it was Kusum who worked on the famous diamond-embellished dress designed for the London Fashion Week.The dress featured diamonds and sapphires, and went onto to becoming one of the most iconic pieces showcased ever at the London Fashion Week.Kusum runs an exclusive jewellery studio where she loves to design and produce something unusual which comes straight from the heart and soul. Her elite royal Rajwara collection is making a lot of noise these days and comprises of designer handmade statement pieces embellished with diamond, other precious stones and real pearls studded in gold and silver.

Title: Valatty: A Golden Retriever and Cocker Spaniel play the leads in this puppy love story
Content: Mollywood has had quite a few popular movies that had animals in important roles, but now, it‚Äôs all set to have a movie entirely set in a dog‚Äôs world. According to the makers of the upcoming Mollywood film Valatty , it is probably the first film in the country to tell its story through dogs ‚Äì with canines of different breeds playing the hero, heroine, villain, sidekicks and more, and the humans are relegated to minor supporting acts.The film‚Äôs director and debutant Devan tells us, ‚ÄúValatty is a story of romance. We are using real dogs and no VFX at all. For the past one year, we have been training the pups cast in the film. We had a 2.5 acre area in Kollam, where the trainers and those working on the film including me lived in a house with these pups, so that they were trained and also got acquainted with us. All of us are dog lovers, so we want to make this film in the most naturally possible way, by giving them their space and time.‚Äù The crew plans to start the shoot next month.Tomy, a Golden Retriever is the hero of the film, while Amalu, a Cocker Spaniel , is the heroine. An indigenous breed canine named Karidas and Bruno, a Rottweiler, play the other major characters. Devan says, ‚ÄúThose were their names we chose for them when they were pups and we are using the same in the film too.‚ÄùThe team is planning to start the shoot next month. ‚ÄúThe story is not region specific, so we are going for neutral locations,‚Äù says Devan. Ask him who would be dubbing for the canines in the movie and he says, ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt reveal that now.‚ÄùDue to Covid-19 restrictions, the director says that he team will have a small schedule first with minimal crew and indoors. ‚ÄúWe will have to go slow as this is a different kind of movie involving dogs. Also, we will plan the next schedule only after observing how the first schedule turns out,‚Äù he says.

Title: Film exhibitors worried about burden of SOPs to reopen movie halls
Content: Movie halls across the country have been shut for over four months, and even though two phases of lockdown relaxations were implemented, there was no word on cinema exhibition. The buzz now, though, is that movie theatres will be on the list of businesses that can reopen as part of Unlock 3. According to those in the know, the state government is awaiting clearance from the Centre to announce the opening of theatres from August 1, subject to stringent measures on occupancy, sanitisation, social distancing and show timings. Speaking to us, President of the Karnataka Film Exhibitors Association President, KV Chandrashekhara says, ‚ÄúWe have incurred losses to the tune of `150 crore in the four months that theatres have been closed. Movie halls being included in the next unlock phase is good news for us. But the future is far from rosy, considering that 25% is the maximum allowed occupancy when we do reopen. It remains to be seen if we will we able to even get to those numbers, as people are still wary of venturing to public places and contracting the coronavirus . A large chunk of our audience are college-going youngsters, who now have online classes and will not be out and about. Family audiences may also stay away, considering that children below 10 and the elderly should not step out. Even if the Centre allows theatres to reopen on August 1, we will have to wait for guidelines from the state government before throwing our doors open to audiences.‚ÄùPresident of Mysore Theatres Owners Association, MR Rajaram, says, ‚ÄúIf we reopen with 25% occupancy, our operational costs will exceed the income and affect our business module. A month‚Äôs electric bill of a normal single-screen theatre can run up to `50,000 per month, which cannot be recovered with the 25% occupancy per show. Thermal screening of movie goers and regular sanitization of the hall and seats need to be carried out, costs of which have to be borne by exhibitors. In the best interest of the business, the government should look at allowing at least 50%, else theatre owners may just shut shop and convert the premises into something more commercially viable.‚ÄùAnother theatre owner, Subramanyam, adds, ‚ÄúThere will be challenges when theatres are opened to the public. Show timings will have to be changed to factor in sanitisation of the hall and seats after every screening. If the 9 pm curfew continues, the last show will have to start around 5.30-6 pm. We will have to work out timings backward from there. These issues need to be sorted out before we reopen.‚Äù

Title: #MonsoonHacks: How to keep your wardrobe fresh and fragrant
Content: When was the last time you neatly organised your wardrobe or took a peek inside your shoe rack? If you haven‚Äôt so far, then it‚Äôs high time you did. It‚Äôs monsoon after all. Open the closet and check if your favourite denims smell damp and musty. Since most of us are working from homes and do not need to dress up often, chances are that our clothes and shoes have already become the breeding ground for pesky little mould spores. But worry not! Here are some interesting storage hacks that you must follow to keep your wardrobe clean and fresh during monsoon...Use old newspaper lining on the shelves. Paper controls the humidity inside a closed space.Place a bag of salt in your wardrobe. It absorbs moisture. You can also put some sticks of chalk to keep your clothes dry.Take a muslin bag. Fill some camphor and put it in your closet. Camphor not only absorbs moisture, but makes your cupboard smell good too.Put some dried neem leaves in one corner of your wardrobe. This age-old trick keeps all kinds of microbes at bay and your clothes remain crisp and fresh.Insert a few naphthalene balls between your clothes. Naphthalene wards off insects and termites. It also thwarts the growth of microbes.Mould is a fungus that grows due to rising humidity in the air and lack of ventilation. Minimise moisture by making sure your wardrobe isn‚Äôt tightly fitted against the wall. Leave some space in between. If you‚Äôre keeping clothes that you don‚Äôt plan to wear in the near future, vacuum seal them to prevent moisture getting in. It‚Äôs important to de-clutter your wardrobe once in a while. Clothes stacked in your wardrobe for a long time can develop mould. Make sure your clothes are always dry. If possible, hang them in the sun before storing.Monsoon is the time when you really need to worry about your footwear and bags. Be it leather, cloth or suede, your shoes and bags should be moisture-free. Clean them with wax polish or duster brush and wrap them in thin bags made of cloth. You can order them online.Put silica gel packets inside your shoes and bags before wrapping them. It absorbs moisture and bad odour.Plastic bags can trap moisture and spoil the leather. So, wrap your bags in muslin.Try to keep camphor, naphthalene, salt in the cabinet where you store shoes.Use a hair dryer to dry your shoes and bags once in a while.

Title: Poetry festivals go online, with better reach, more artistes
Content:
Reaching a largeru audience

Online events are here to stay

As events continue to take the online route in the midst of the pandemic, literary events like poetry festivals too are joining the bandwagon. In fact, poetry festivals are making the most of the online medium and in the process, reaching out to a wider audience and participants.Case in point, is the annual Bengaluru Poetry Festival (BPF) that‚Äôs going online this year. The festival sees several literary names, celebs and performers in attendance and will be held in August. ‚ÄúInitially, even we thought that we wouldn‚Äôt organise the festival this year, because the charm of BPF lies in the intimate gatherings, where discussions, debates and performances are held with poets and poetry lovers from across the world. However, Shinie Anthony , who is the festival director, said that we had to do this and keep the spirit alive,‚Äù explains Subodh Shankar , a member of the organising team.Similarly, the Glasshouse Festival ‚Äì Poetry from Around the World, which was held online recently, was also a first for the organising team. ‚ÄúThough we have conducted several virtual events earlier, this was the first time we organised the festival online. It was a mix of poetry and music performances,‚Äù says Raji Narayan, president of Art Mantaram Trust , a non-profit organisation that was behind the festival.Organisers also point out that online festivals are allowing them to reach out to more artistes and a larger audience. ‚ÄúThis year, we have poets such as Gregory Kan, Avner Pariat, Roland Jurczok, Venus Jones, among others from India as well. If we had to reach out to the same names for a physical event, that wouldn‚Äôt be possible due to logistical issues. Also, people from around the world can watch them perform now,‚Äù says Subodh, adding, ‚ÄúUnlike most events, which are live streamed these days, we will have recorded events, readings and performances, that will be up on the festival‚Äôs website. People will be able to watch the videos anytime they want.‚ÄùRaji adds that in addition to reaching out to a bigger audience, virtual festivals also fire the creativity of the organisers. ‚ÄúIt pushes us to do our best and ensure that the audiences have a seamless experience. We had poets like Sonia Sanchez , Satchidanandan K , Jennifer Foerster and Norduran Duman, to name a few. As organisers we are on our toes and prepared for any situation, even while working from home,‚Äù she shares, adding that audiences have gotten comfortable with the idea of ‚Äòentertainment from home‚Äô. ‚ÄúWe have become so comfortable with entertainment from home, that for the next few months, this is how things will be even if venues were to open for the public,‚Äù she feels.

Title: Sembaruthi team provides a glimpse into COVID-era TV Shoots
Content: It‚Äôs always fun to be on a television set. Actors are usually hanging out together and chatting during breaks, while technicians are super busy, running around and setting up the next scene. However, things are different in the post-COVID-19 scenario, as we found out when we visited the shooting spot of Sembaruthi. The usually buzzing set was a lot quieter. The cast and crew walked in with masks, sanitised themselves, got their temperature checked and then walked into the set.Dinesh, who‚Äôs producing the serial, says, ‚ÄúIn view of the current restrictions, we are trying our best to work with limited resources and bring alive the story for our viewers in the safest way possible.‚Äù Ask him if the plot has been tweaked to bring in the COVID-19 angle, and he says, ‚ÄúWe are not making any direct references to the pandemic. While the storyline may show some of our present realities (such as washing hands frequently, using hand sanitisers, etc.), we still want the show to be viewed as a positive escape from the current difficult circumstances.‚ÄùWe are very conscious while working and ensure we maintain distance while talking and doing our scenes. We wear our mask even after doing our makeup. Irrespective of the situation, we all need to look presentable on screen, right? So, we do touch-up more often than before. The whole shooting process has totally changed. However, it feels nice to be back on the set.- Shabana Shajahan, who plays the female lead, ParvatyShooting in this new normal is challenging. It isn‚Äôt easy to wear a mask throughout the day. But we need to do it for our own safety. The team, too, is taking several precautions to ensure we are safe. We sanitise or wash our hands with soap every time we touch an object (as part of the shoot).- Sanjay Kumar Asrani, who plays PurshothamanThe unit is putting in a lot of effort to keep us safe. We, as artistes, need to keep that in mind and take care of ourselves while shooting. Like others mentioned, things have changed for sure. We don‚Äôt sit together anymore and are usually in our rooms. We come to the spot only when our scenes are being shot. It is definitely difficult to shoot without ACs, and that, too, in this humid weather. But we need to be cautious.- Lakshmi, who plays Vanaja

Title: A staff member of TV show Bhakarwadi dies due to COVID-19; few others test positive: confirms producer JD Majethia
Content:
Read Also

Read Also

In a shocking turn of events, a staff member from TV show Bhakarwadi , produced by JD Majethia, passed away due to coronavirus on July 21. Producer JD Majethia confirmed the news to Etimes TV and shared that a few others have also been infected with the virus, but they are in quarantine and undergoing treatment.The staff member, who worked as a tailor with the production house, was doing fine till July 10, but he felt weak the next day and was advised by the nurse on the sets to visit a doctor. He met the doctor and was on medication. On July 13, he asked to visit his family, later the Bhakarwadi team learnt that he passed away on July 21 due to the novel coronavirus.Talking about the incident JD Majethia shared, "A sad incident took place on the sets of Bhakarwadi. The tailor, who passed away, was normal and his parameters were also normal from July 1st. But when he experienced little weakness on July 11 the nurse present on the sets asked him to see a doctor who diagnosed him with viral and gave medicines for cold and weakness. He felt all right and worked on July 12th as well. On July 13, he asked for a leave as he wanted to go home. As per a rule set by our production house we stay in regular contact with people who are not well or have taken a leave. They also have to produce a Doctor's certificate of their well being at the time of resuming the shoot. He was reminded on a group chat on July 10 via message as he had not replied to our calls. He went for a test on July 20 and we were shocked to hear about the news of his demise when we called on July 21st. We are in touch with his family members and doing the needful."The Production house immediately arranged for a swab test for the rest of the cast and crew, "The next step was to identify the people who came in close contact and we got them all tested. One person tested positive out of them and we knew we were in a very challenging situation so went for consultations of the best of doctors at Kokilaben Ambani hospital. We spoke to Dr Sushant Joshi who is almost like an authority on this issue for the state. He did the swab test of more than 70 people with a reputed diagnostic centre which included actors, technicians, workers, substitutes resting at home , day today actors, drivers, studio staff, suppliers etc. and a few of them have tested positive for COVID-19 . They have been taken care of and are quarantined as per the required government guidelines. Shoot was stopped for three days again as per government guidelines and to be on safer side will not shoot tomorrow also for the 4th day. We all need to put in collective efforts to fight this situation. We will share more learning from the experience so that others can benefit from it. We are surprised and shocked with the kind of young people who have tested positive. There were no symptoms in most of them and they are hale and hearty. But such is the character of this virus. We request each and every one to not forget three things for a split second also, Mask, sanitizer, and social distancing," he shared.JD Majethia, who has produced several hit shows like Baa Bahoo Aur Baby, Khichdi, Sarabhai vs Sarabhai, shared that they followed all the norms but still the virus took away a life, "We too followed every requirement and care but the virus takes just a split of second to defeat you. Our unit will be more vigilant when we resume our shoot next," he said.

Title: Rhea Chakroborty's lawyer arrives at her residence after Sushant Singh Rajput's father files FIR against her
Content: Sushant Singh Rajput's father recently filed an FIR at Rajiv Nagar police station in Patna alleging Rhea of cheating for financial gains and abetting the actor to commit suicide. The actress has been booked on charges of unlawful confinement and abetment of suicide in Sushant Singh Rajput 's death case.Now, on Tuesday, Rhea's lawyer Anandini Fernandes was snapped as she arrived at the actress' residence in Mumbai. Check out the pictures here:Sushant passed away on June 14 at his Bandra residence. Currently, the Mumbai Police is investigating the case and several big-wigs of Bollywood like Aditya Chopra Sanjay Leela Bhansali , Apoorva Mehta and Mahesh Bhatt have recorded their statement with the cops.On the other hand, SSR's fans have been demanding a CBI enquiry of the case for a long time now.Recently, Rhea had requested Union Home Minister Amit Shah for a CBI inquiry into Sushant's untimely demise. Sharing a picture of the late actor, she wrote, "Respected @amitshahofficial sir, I‚Äôm Sushant Singh Rajput's girlfriend Rhea Chakraborty , it is now over a month since his sudden demise. I have complete faith in the government, however, in the interest of justice, I request you with folded hands to initiate a CBI enquiry into this matter. I only want to understand what pressures prompted Sushant to take this step."

Title: Kunal Kemmu showcases his 'dark' side
Content: Just a few days ago, Neha Dhupia shared a picture of hers in black-and-white, and it was shot by Kunal Kemmu . The actor has now shared a few black-and-white pictures of himself, and they are quite interesting. In the picture above, he captioned it with just one word: " Dark ". However, in another monochrome picture of himself, he can be seen lying on his back, with his head on a sill of a building terrace, with birds flying in the sky above him. Shot by Shivaji Storm Sen, the actor captioned the picture as: "Floating between elements and dimensions."However, not everything has been black-and-white for the actor, whose film 'Lootcase' is set to get an OTT release on July 31. Sharing a throwback of ' Hum Hain Rahi Pyar Ke ', where he featured as a child star alongside Aamir Khan and Juhi Chawla, he wrote: "Although I‚Äôm not sure about the exact day but it released in this month 27 years ago (I trust google)." After that film, he would go on to become one of the most popular child actors in the nineties with films like 'Raja Hindustani', 'Bhai', etc. His film 'Zakhm', where he played a young Ajay Devgn, won a National Award for the Best Actor for Devgn and Nargis Dutt Award for Best Feature Film on National Integration.

Title: Anupam Shyam needs money for kidney transplant, says the veteran actor‚Äôs brother
Content: Veteran actor Anupam Shyam , 62, who is better known as Thakur Sajjan Singh from Mann Ki Awaaz Pratigya , was admitted to the ICU of a suburban hospital, after he complained of breathlessness.His brother, Anurag, who lives with him, told us, ‚ÄúAnupam bhaiyya has been diabetic for almost 40 years and also has high blood pressure. A few years ago, he had also suffered a heart problem and the doctors had then told him that he had a blockage. He was put on heavy medication, which harmed his kidneys. It resulted in pulmonary edema. He was required to undergo dialysis regularly, but he stopped it about a year ago due to money crunch. His condition deteriorated and I got him admitted to the hospital on Monday night. He has exhausted all his savings on medical expenses. I borrowed some money from people for his dialysis around 10 days ago. The doctors have suggested a kidney transplant. We have no clue how we will get it done, as he doesn‚Äôt have enough money for it.‚ÄùThe actor has featured in several films, including ' Satya ', ' Pyar To Hona Hi Tha ', 'Kachche Dhaage', 'Nayak: The Real Hero' and ' Munna Michael '. He has also been a part of TV shows like 'Hum Ne Li Hai - Shapath', Doli Armaano Ki' and 'Krishna Chali London'.

Title: Leveraging The Flexibility Of Online Learning
Content: The world is moving at a fast pace, but the question is, are we moving fast enough to catch up?The sudden changes in our lifestyles have taken most of us by surprise. And yet, some of them come with their fair share of upsides.One such area is that of online classes and virtual learning platforms.Education has become more accessible, flexible and affordable through various virtual platforms. Removing the barriers of place, time and speed of study, online classes have the scope of providing a unique learning environment to every child. Having said that, like every coin has two sides, online education may also send a child down a whole different path.Exactly why, there are a few prerequisites to effective online education.Here are a few requisites for you to leverage the flexibility of online learning for your child or student:Bridge The Distance Between Goals And Accomplishments With DisciplineHow does one live up to their plans? Well, with discipline, of course. Discipline will help you leverage the flexibility of learning through virtual classrooms and ensure that you stick to your plans in the absence of an external monitor.Helping your kid live a disciplined life even through distance learning is going to go a long way.It is true that distance learning removes a lot of barriers which the traditional form of learning sets up. However, it is also true that e-learning would require an extra effort on your part. Do the necessary research, plan out a good part of your child‚Äôs day and make it a point that you monitor their learning.If they do not feel like studying alone, sit with them and take the class. Make notes together and please, oh, please, have fun while doing all of it. There is no reason to make the process cumbersome and heavy.One of the most common teaching FAQs out there is, ‚ÄúHow to make the child practice?‚ÄùWell, in our opinion, the best way is to lead by example. Show your child first-hand how practice helps with better retention of knowledge and with helping them consume and understand what they are studying.It could be as simple as making paper boats with them and showing them how you will not stop until you get a perfect one.Enabling your child to process the importance of practice will help them enjoy the flexibility of their online education while taking up responsibilities on their own!The Millenials and The Gen Z are not here with a boon to be technologically advanced. It is just a matter of a few hours of effective learning. Go on Youtube or pick up a book or use Google, but find out how to take online classes, how to operate your Intel powered Dell or HP or Lenovo or any other laptop and make sure you are already learned in the field of online learning well before your child starts taking those classes. Learning how to operate a computer may look like rocket science, but it is not! Never forget that.Now that your child is going to be living at his school or in other words, learning or getting an education at home, it is extremely important that you strike a balance between their educational and personal part of the day.Also, since they will be spending quite a lot of time on-screen, it is important for them to spend some time off-screen too. In other words, try and strike a balance in all aspects of their day for it will help them with the overall development of personality.E-learning is here to stay and the faster we accommodate it, the better. Make use of your extra time to help yourself, and your child develop a great and unbreakable bond of trust and love.Leverage the flexibility of online learning and don‚Äôt stop until your goal is achieved!All the best!--------------------------------------------------------------PC Paathshala is an industry initiative by Intel in India with The Times Of India and multiple PC ecosystem players, to enable students, teachers and parents to adapt to online learning. The platform provides easy to understand articles, videos, workshops, webinars, FAQs and much more targeted towards enabling the key stakeholders to transition from classroom learning to e-learning. Key partners to the initiative include brands like Acer, Asus, Dell, HP, Lenovo, Khan Academy, Kopykitab, Udemy, Amazon, Croma, Flipkart, Panache, Recherche, Reliance Digital, Shopclues and Snapdeal. Visit www.pcpaathshala.com to know more.

Title: Nikkhil Arya: I didn‚Äôt test positive for COVID-19, I was admitted to hospital for a surgery
Content: A couple of days ago, actor Nikkhil Arya was admitted to hospital because of which it was speculated that he had tested positive for coronavirus. However, we have got to know that he underwent an appendicitis surgery on Sunday morning in his hometown, Pune.When we reached out to him, he texted back, saying, ‚ÄúIt started out as a regular stomach ache, which I thought was a case of acidity and indigestion. But, it turned out to be a badly swollen appendix, and became more complicated and painful because it ruptured and the pus spread inside my stomach. If I had delayed it a little more, anything could‚Äôve happened. God is great.‚ÄùAbout rumours that he had tested positive for COVID-19, he clarified, ‚ÄúThe good news is that I am COVID negative for the time being, but my city Pune continues to bleed and deliver horrific numbers.‚Äù

Title: Rs 40 theft: India Government Mint employee faces up to 7 years in jail for 'stealing' two unreleased Rs 20 coins
Content:
MRA Marg police

Prime Minister Narendra Modi

Ministry of Defence

educational institutions

social service institutions

Bureau of Indian Standards

‚ÄòLoose change‚Äô he allegedly stole was in the form of two unreleased Rs 20 coins.An employee of the India Government Mint at Fort faces up to seven years in jail for allegedly stealing the equivalent of four vada pavs. Thebooked R R Chabukswar on Monday after two yet-to-be released Rs 20 coins were found in his locker the previous day. The police are investigating whether this was the first time he had stolen coins from the mint.Acting on a tip-off, Samsher Sajjuram, a Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) inspector posted at the mint, had Chabukswar‚Äôs locker opened on Sunday in front of two witnesses. Inside, he found two of the unreleased coins. The tip-off came from sub-inspector Niyaz Mohammad, who had heard from a source that Chabukswar had hidden some coins in his locker. Chabukswar was booked under Section 381 of the Indian Penal Code (theft by a clerk of property owned by his/her employer), which carries a maximum sentence of seven years, a police official said.The official said that while Chabukswar had managed to hide the two coins in his locker, he would have found it much harder to smuggle them out of the mint, as all employees are frisked by CISF guards when entering or leaving. He added, however, that Chabukswar probably stole the coins out of curiosity rather than a desire to make money. The police are yet to arrest him, and have sent him a notice asking him to cooperate with the investigation. An official said, ‚ÄúThe police have not immediately arrested the accused due to the Covid-19 situation. The punishment for this crime is up to seven years in jail. We have sent him a notice asking him to co-operate with our probe.‚ÄùThe new Rs 20 coin is part of a series thathad unveiled in March 2019, which also included new Re 1, Rs 2, Rs 5 and Rs 10 coins. The Rs 2, Rs 5 and Rs 10 coins are already in circulation. The Rs 20 coin was expected in April but its introduction was delayed by the pandemic.According to the Finance Ministry‚Äôs notification, the Rs 20 coin - the highest-denomination coin minted in India to date - will be in the shape of a dodecagon, a 12-sided polygon. Like the Rs 10 coin from the series, it will be twotoned. The outer ring will be 65 per cent copper, 15 per cent zinc and 20 per nickel, while the inner disc will be 75 per cent copper, 20 per cent zinc and five per cent nickel. But unlike the circular Rs 10 coin, which has 100 serrations on its edge, the Rs 20 coin will not have any marks on its edge.Established in 1829, the Mumbai mint is one of four in India. The other three are in Hyderabad, Kolkata and Noida. Apart from regular and commemorative coins, it produces medals for the, Ministry of Home Affairs,and. It also produces official weights and measures for state governments, laboratories and the

Title: Uttarakhand‚Äôs Van Gujjars now back to milking their fortune
Content:
They dumped 5,000 litres of milk down the drain every day after lockdown began. Then, fought

and travel curbs to get back to business

(This story is part of a series in association with Facebook. Facebook has no editorial role in this story.)

Every day in April, the 800-odd Van Gujjar families in Haridwar‚Äôs Gaindikhata area would dump 5,000 litres of milk down the drain. The lockdown had been hard on most, harder still on the forest-dwelling community with no other means of livelihood.In April, one member of the Van Gujjar community tested positive for Covid-19. The entire settlement was sealed as a containment zone for about a month. They could not step out and sell milk, which goes bad quickly. While they waited it out, 98 people from Gaindikhata who had attended the Tablighi Jamaat in Delhi and elsewhere, were identified. The Covid stigma got worse. And while the containment zone was unsealed, customers shut their doors on the Van Gujjars ‚ÄúThey said the milk may be infected. People took advantage of us. We even sold milk at Rs 15 a litre. In all this, some started asking if we are members of Tablighi Jamaat. We follow Sufi Islam. But it didn‚Äôt seem to matter,‚Äù said Muhammad Alam, a member of the community.The pastoralist tribe, which lives near the Rajaji Tiger Reserve, is entirely dependent on its buffalo herds for survival. So while they couldn‚Äôt change what they did to make a living, they could change where they did it. So in June, some of the younger people decided to start exploring markets further away.‚ÄúTravelling was restricted ‚Äî sometimes we‚Äôd face lathicharge when anyone heard we were from Gaindikhata. So we tried to let others know by word of mouth,‚Äù said Muhammad Gulam, who runs a wholesale milk business at Gaindikhata. ‚ÄúIt took some effort and a lot of time, but we slowly started getting customers in places much further away ‚Äî Rishikesh (about 40 km) and Roorkee (about 50 km).‚Äù‚ÄúWe are selling milk at the correct prices of Rs 50-60 a litre again. We have new customers, business is brisk. And this seems to have encouraged our earlier customers too, who are all getting around to buying milk from us again,‚Äù said Alam.The owner of one of the largest dairies in Rishikesh, Sardar Puran Kainth, said even he harboured some apprehensions initially. ‚ÄúSince the lockdown began, we had not been sure about where to procure our milk from. But things are back to normal now. We will keep up our business with the Van Gujjars,‚Äù he said.

Title: From monotone to designer, Lucknowites now want fancy masks
Content:
SURVIVAL OF THE MOST CREATIVE

(BCCL)

JUST KIDDING WITH MASKS

FASHIONISTAS‚Äô THUMBS UP TO THE TREND

Eesha Punjabi has been designing customised masks (BCCL)

MASK: THE

NEW FASHION ACCESSORY

COUPLED WITH A MASK!

With major fashion trends taking a back seat ever since the Coronavirus outbreak happened in the country, a very prominent emerging fashion trend is that of designer masks . City designers are now going all out to woo Lucknowites with some funky customised masks. Read on...For designer Prakhar Tandon , owner of a chikan shops in Bhoothnath, designing masks is all about survival now. ‚ÄúSee, people are not going out anywhere, so we hardly have sales of clothes. Since we deal mostly in chikan work, we sat with our workers and looked for innovation in the field. We have designed exclusive different layered chikan masks on different fabrics which are selling like hotcakes not only in the city but also online. The trend is here to stay for very long, as I predict.‚Äù(BCCL)Madhu Bhatia, a retired teacher, started making masks to distribute to the Covid frontline warriors working nearing her house. But seeing how beautiful they were, her neighbours asked her to make some for them too. ‚ÄúSeeing how necessary a mask is these days. I thought of giving them a better look. I had cloth pieces lying at home and I started making embroidered ones, ones with tissue, Banarasi zari fabric, which people loved. And now I have so many orders, it sometimes becomes difficult to fulfil all of them,‚Äù says Bhatia. ‚ÄúThen the kids started complaining that I‚Äôve given their mother such beautiful masks and why not them? So that prompted me to design masks for kids," says Madhu.Lalita Pandey, a bureaucrat, gets hundreds of likes on social media when she posts pictures of matching masks that she wears with her outfits. ‚ÄúMasks are now mandatory, so why not wear beautiful ones which you can show off apart from keeping yourself safe,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWomen want to be seen as fashionable, they would obviously want to wear fashionable masks than wear something which is dull and suufocating,‚Äù adds Lalita.Eesha Punjabi has been designing customised masks (BCCL)Poonam Mehrotra, a designer in Indira Nagar, happened to make hand painted masks which proved to be a big hit with her customers. ‚ÄúIt began with my experimenting with masks that I had stitched and painting Madhubani motifs on them. When my friends saw them they loved them and I was literally flooded with orders. So much so that I am now sending masks to people in the US and also all over India.‚Äù Poonam goes on to add, ‚ÄúMasks are now a necessity, and have become a fashion accessory. We designers now have to be innovative in designing this new fashion accessory.‚ÄùWith weddings taking place now, Eesha Punjabi, a designer and owner of a fashion studio in the city, has begun designing customised masks for the bride and the groom. ‚ÄúThe demand for designer masks is really high. While earlier the baraatis used to be gifted stoles, now they are getting designer masks. Plus, the bride and groom too are getting customised masks made for themselves. Even youngsters now want masks with either their initials or their partner‚Äôs initials.‚Äù

Title: Ayushmann Khurrana to play a cross functional athlete in Abhishek Kapoor‚Äôs untitled love story
Content: One is an actor, who has toplined content-driven films as diverse as Bareilly Ki Barfi AndhaDhun , Badhaai Ho and Shubh Mangal Saavdhan . And the other is known for movies like Rock On!! Kai Po Che and Kedarnath . And now, the two ‚Äî Ayushmann Khurrana and Abhishek Kapoor ‚Äî are all set to join hands for the first time.BT has it that the yet-untitled film, which is a progressive love story, is set in North India and will go on floors this October. It will present Ayushmann in a never-seen-before avatar ‚Äî that of a cross functional athlete.We reached out to Abhishek, who confirmed the news. He said, ‚ÄúAyushmann will have to undergo a physical transformation for this role. It‚Äôs quite a challenge and he‚Äôs committed to it.‚ÄùThe actor, too, is excited about starting work on this project. He told us, ‚ÄúAbhishek has a distinct voice in cinema today, and I‚Äôm glad that we finally got the opportunity to work together on a project that‚Äôs close to my heart. This beautiful love story will take viewers on an emotional roller-coaster ride and it is a total family entertainer.‚ÄùTalking about the physical transformation that he will have to go through, he added, ‚ÄúI have never attempted a look like this on screen before and I‚Äôm already looking forward to seeing the reaction of audiences. The process is going to be intense and excruciating, but I feel that the pain will be worth it.‚ÄùMeanwhile, Abhishek is hopeful that viewers will be back in theatres by the time his film releases next year. Title: Ranvir Shorey: I'm cynical now. I've seen too much. Nothing really changes
Content: Amidst the anger and debate following Sushant Singh Rajput 's death, Ranvir Shorey has been one of the more vocal voices commenting on the functioning of the cine industry Nila Madhab Panda , an 'outsider' himself, who has directed Ranvir in ' Kadvi Hawa' and ' Halkaa', asks him what‚Äôs got him so upset and if he thinks anything's really going to change in the power dynamics of the industry. Excerpts from the chat:Ranvir: Right now, the debate going on is about mainstream Bollywood, it is not about the Indian or Hindi film industry . It is about that group within a group, the top of the pyramid of mainstream Bollywood. Every actor aspires to be at the top, what happens is that you hit a glass ceiling, or you enter the gatekeeper zone where approval of a select few people can give you access to the top, otherwise you keep working for smaller rewards.Taking Sushant's example, he had been doing very well on his own. He had blockbusters under his belt but, like even Anurag (Kashyap) mentioned in one of his interviews, he wanted validation from this group, this cabal. These people wield a lot of power in terms of distribution and exhibition of cinema and marketing budgets. Seeking validation from these people is what I think went wrong for him.Ranvir: No matter how good a film is made, when you are not going to get shows in the cinema halls, what are you going to do? Dekho agar kisi ke paas power ho toh accountability honi chahiye, agar accountability nahi hai toh grace honi chahiye. Inke paas dono nahi hai. Anybody who has power doesn't want to let go of it. And they end up abusing that power.Ranvir: After Sushant's death, I was also devastated, thinking what the hell happened! When the circumstances around his death started being discussed and the names of the people he was involved with started coming out, I was shocked. These were the same names, same people involved at the time when I went through all this in 2003-05, the same circumstances. The psychological pressures were created for him also.First, you isolate someone at work. And in our business what happens is if you isolate someone at work, their social life is also affected. Aapko bade banner ne liya toh aapke dus dost hain, aapko bade banner ne drop kiya toh suddenly you have only three friends left. I was reading that his girlfriend was being told by one mainstream director that you better let this guy go or else you will also suffer. Then she also left him. What is the guy left with then? You isolate him socially, professionally, and then one last thing that a young man in his thirties would want to hold on to, his girlfriend, you affect that also. He just didn't know what hit him.When these things came out and the names of the persons involved were the same that I had suffered at the hands of, with no accountability, that's when I started speaking. And I was upset that if Kangana is talking about this, why are people asking her to keep quiet? Why should she not speak?Ranvir: For the disparity in power for distribution and exhibition, the streaming platforms will be equalisers. Marketing and media will be equalised a little with social media. These things will bring a little relief, but it's not that the world order will change once theatres reopen. The same people will still be in power.Un logon ko fark nahi padta hai. People like you and me, those who don't enjoy that privilege, hum log kabhi aise bol sakte hain, ki kaisi bhi film bana dete hain, 100 crore toh ye banayegi hi kyunki shows toh mere paas hain. Main aisa performance de sakta hoon, ki arey yaar main kuch bhi kar deta hoon, public toh taali maregi. Toh incentive hi nahi hai better kaam karne ka. Isiliye inki filmein itni gandi banti hai. Doesn't matter how many crores they make, but they make s**t films.Ranvir: Woh joh hope hota hai na ‚Äì ki mere ko bhi kabhi mainstream picture milegi, 100 crore ki picture banegi ‚Äì woh toh inn logon ne pehle hi maar diya hai. So mere ko fark nahi padta. I have stopped wanting to please those people for a while now. Thankfully, there are talented filmmakers like you who have faith in me. There are people like Rajat, Abhishek Chaubey , these are people who care about cinema, who care about making good films. I am very happy doing this. Mere ko big reward chahiye hi nahi, main small reward mein khush hoon.But many don't want to burn the chance they might get later of being accepted by the cabal. And you can't judge them for it either.Ranvir: The hoo-ha on social media with hashtags is not a reflection of what is happening in the real world. Once theatres open up, we might see a small difference in the disparity, the desperation and the despair that exists ‚Äì that will be because of the presence of streaming platforms as a safety valve. But I have a feeling that the theatre game is going to go back to the same. I am a cynical man now. I have seen too much. Nothing really changes.

Title: Actor, playwright, screenwriter, author & journalist, Raavi Kondala Rao leaves behind a glorious legacy
Content: Telugu cinema lost another doyen with the passing away of Raavi Kondala Rao due to a cardiac arrest in Hyderabad on Tuesday. He was 88. Rao was suffering from several heart-related ailments and his health reportedly deteriorated over the last few weeks. Born on February 11, 1932 in Samarlakota, Andhra Pradesh, Raavi Kondala Rao had acted in over 600 films in a career spanning six decades. He started his journey as an actor with the film Shobha starring the late NTR in 1958. Having started out as Assistant Editor, Rao soon showcased his talent as an actor and went on to feature in several hit films, including Tene Manasulu, Dasara Bullodu, Rangoon Rowdy, Edurinti Mogudu Pakkinti Pellam, Varakatnam, Andara Ramudu, Radha Kalyanam, etc. He also dubbed for various Tamil and Malayalam films.A journalist and an author, Rao was a sub-editor in the popular Telugu magazine Vijaya Chitra for 36 years. Over the years, he worked as an editor and columnist for major Telugu dailies covering various topics.His wife Radha Kumari was also a well-known actress and the duo had worked together in several movies. Radha Kumari passed away in 2012 when Rao was on his way to the UAE to collect an award. He later said that he was shaken by the loss and his spirit was never the same again. Rao was also an illustrious writer and is known for his work in films like Bhairava Dweepam, Brundavanam and Pelli Pustakam , for which he received a Nandi award. Rao also received a Nandi award for his book Black & White in 2004.‚ÄúApart from acting and writing, Rao left behind a great legacy in the fields of theatre and mimicry. He had a wonderful sense of humour, which reflected in his writing as well as his personality. I had the good fortune of working with him right from the beginning of my career. A mutlifaceted genius, Raavi Kondala Rao leaves behind a void in Telugu cinema,‚Äù says Chiranjeevi, summing up Kondala Rao‚Äôs contribution as an actor and man of words.An actorMade his debut in the film Sobha starring NTR in 1958His talent as an actor was first noticed by the Telugu audience in the Krishna-starrer Tene Manasula in 1965He went on to star in over 600 films, including Dasara Bullodu, Rangoon Rowdy, Edurinti Mogudu, etcHis last film was 365 Days, which released in February 2020As a screenwriterWrote the story for Bapu-Ramana‚Äôs Pelli Pusthakam, for which he won the Nandi awardSome of the other significant films for which he wrote dialogues for include Bhairava Dweepam, Sri Krishna Yuddham and BrundavanamAs a journalist, he was associate editor at Telugu magazine Vijaya Chitram from 1966 to 1990As an author and playwrightKondala Rao received the Nandi Award for his book titled Black & White in 2004Some of his other popular books include Didruksha and MumoorshaHe had also penned his autobiography titled Naagavali Nunchi Manjeera Varaku in 2015As a playwright, he wrote popular skits like Kukkapilla Dorikindi and Nalugilla Savidi

The novel coronavirus is not the only thing that‚Äôs dangerous at the Bengaluru International Exhibition Centre (BIEC) which has been converted into a. The covid care centre can accommodate 5000 patients and has room for 1500 beds for doctors, nurses and other staff members.‚ÄúBIEC is on the outskirts of the city andare bound to exist here since there is not much interference from people.The BBMP authorities have forgotten to depute snake catchers to this place,‚Äù said the BBMP staffer.There are nine snake catchers authorized by the BBMP to attend to rescue calls all over the city but so far none of them have been summoned to the BIEC while the covid care centre was being set up.The other issue is the delay in clearing the arrears of honorarium for the snake catchers. ‚ÄúWe are yet to receive honorarium for one year. My intention is not to earn money but to save snakes from being killed by the people. The BBMP authorities have not provided us. I happened to rescue snakes from the covid care centre atwithout wearing the PPE kit,‚Äô‚Äô said Jayaraj.Meanwhile, BBMP Deputy Conservator of Forest Ranganatha Swamy said that he will depute snake catchers to the BIEC if the need arises. ‚ÄúI have taken measures to clear the dues to all snake catchers. I will look into the matter of honorarium,‚Äô‚Äô said Ranganatha Swamy.

Title: Rajasthan government firm on July 31 session, says governor's advice ‚Äònot binding‚Äô
Content:
Asked about trust vote, Congress leader says BAC sets agenda

JAIPUR: Adamant about its stand on convening the Rajasthan assembly session from July 31, the Ashok Gehlot government on Tuesday sent yet another proposal ‚Äî its third since July 23 ‚Äî to governor Kalraj Mishra, who a day earlier had advised the government to follow three points, including serving a 21-day notice to legislators before calling the session.Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal told TOI, ‚ÄúThere is no rule binding on us to serve a 21-day notice for calling sessions, which have been convened on much shorter notices on several occasions in the past.‚ÄùThe embattled Congress government‚Äôs fresh proposal does not talk about a trust vote ‚Äî TOI reported on Tuesday that the cabinet wouldn‚Äôt commit itself to one ‚Äî saying that setting an agenda for the House is the right of the assembly‚Äôs business advisory committee (BAC). On Monday, Mishra mentioned that seeking a trust vote could justify convening the assembly at a short notice.On the governor‚Äôs third advice ‚Äî making safety arrangements to counter the Covid-19 risk in the House ‚Äî the government responded that managing the affairs of the Vidhan Sabha was the prerogative of the speaker.Asked if the cabinet has mentioned the trust vote in the revised proposal, Dhariwal said: ‚ÄúThe House agenda is decided by the BAC. We want to discuss the state‚Äôs Covid-19 and financial conditions. Other issues could be taken up if the BAC approves.‚ÄùAfter a nearly two-hour long cabinet meeting, revenue minister Harish Chaudhary said: ‚ÄúThe governor should let the cabinet‚Äôs rights remain with the cabinet, the speaker‚Äôs right to remain with the speaker and perform his own duty.‚ÄùTransport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas said, ‚ÄúWe have sought the assembly session from July 31 as recommended by the cabinet earlier also.‚ÄùOn the governor returning the cabinet recommendations twice between July 24 and 27, transport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas said: ‚ÄúIf the President denies PM Modi‚Äôs call for convening a Lok Sabha session, can the nation function? We do not want a confrontation with the governor, who is the head of our family. But, Article 163 clearly states that a governor cannot reject the cabinet proposal.‚Äù‚ÄúEntire BJP is functioning like slaves of the Congress rebels (Pilot camp). The assembly session will not be convened if these rebels tell the BJP not to do so. Politics is being done ignoring the constitution,‚Äù said Kachariyawas, accusing the BJP of trying to topple the Congress government.

Title: Rajasthan government firm on July 31 session, says governor's advice ‚Äònot binding‚Äô
Content:
Asked about trust vote, Congress leader says BAC sets agenda

JAIPUR: Adamant about its stand on convening the Rajasthan assembly session from July 31, the Ashok Gehlot government on Tuesday sent yet another proposal ‚Äî its third since July 23 ‚Äî to governor Kalraj Mishra, who a day earlier had advised the government to follow three points, including serving a 21-day notice to legislators before calling the session.Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal told TOI, ‚ÄúThere is no rule binding on us to serve a 21-day notice for calling sessions, which have been convened on much shorter notices on several occasions in the past.‚ÄùThe embattled Congress government‚Äôs fresh proposal does not talk about a trust vote ‚Äî TOI reported on Tuesday that the cabinet wouldn‚Äôt commit itself to one ‚Äî saying that setting an agenda for the House is the right of the assembly‚Äôs business advisory committee (BAC). On Monday, Mishra mentioned that seeking a trust vote could justify convening the assembly at a short notice.On the governor‚Äôs third advice ‚Äî making safety arrangements to counter the Covid-19 risk in the House ‚Äî the government responded that managing the affairs of the Vidhan Sabha was the prerogative of the speaker.Asked if the cabinet has mentioned the trust vote in the revised proposal, Dhariwal said: ‚ÄúThe House agenda is decided by the BAC. We want to discuss the state‚Äôs Covid-19 and financial conditions. Other issues could be taken up if the BAC approves.‚ÄùAfter a nearly two-hour long cabinet meeting, revenue minister Harish Chaudhary said: ‚ÄúThe governor should let the cabinet‚Äôs rights remain with the cabinet, the speaker‚Äôs right to remain with the speaker and perform his own duty.‚ÄùTransport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas said, ‚ÄúWe have sought the assembly session from July 31 as recommended by the cabinet earlier also.‚ÄùOn the governor returning the cabinet recommendations twice between July 24 and 27, transport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas said: ‚ÄúIf the President denies PM Modi‚Äôs call for convening a Lok Sabha session, can the nation function? We do not want a confrontation with the governor, who is the head of our family. But, Article 163 clearly states that a governor cannot reject the cabinet proposal.‚Äù‚ÄúEntire BJP is functioning like slaves of the Congress rebels (Pilot camp). The assembly session will not be convened if these rebels tell the BJP not to do so. Politics is being done ignoring the constitution,‚Äù said Kachariyawas, accusing the BJP of trying to topple the Congress government.

Title: Signs to help you know that your dog might be sick
Content: You as a dog parent play a crucial role in helping your dog combat illness and remain as healthy as possible. Your furry friend obviously can't describe the symptoms to you, but it can surely show you signs of disease if any. But, as a dog parent, you must keep yourself aware of the signs of the most common diseases in order to help reduce your pet's risk of being affected by any. Hence, we got you a little information on the same.- Appetite change, weight loss , weight gain.- Bad breath or drooling.- Change in activity level. - Sleeping more than normal or other behavioural changes- Coughing, excessive panting, sneezing.- Stiffness or difficulty in rising or climbing stairs.- Dry skin, lumps, shaking of the head.- Dry, red or cloudy eyes.If your dog shows any of these symptoms of being ill, you must immediately contact your veterinarian.Since the signs of disease are not always seen clearly, the veterinarian might recommend some preventive care testing so as to be sure of the symptoms.- Urine tests to screen for urinary tract infection and another disease.- A complete blood count to rule out any blood-related conditions.- Tests to identify if your pet has any tick-borne, heartworm or any infectious diseases.- A thyroid test so as to determine if the thyroid gland is producing very little thyroid hormone.- An ECG that screens for an abnormal heart rhythm, which can help in indicating any underlying heart conditions.

Title: Sunil Grover: Sunil Grover: No one finds me woman enough to challenge, still I accept the B/W challenge
Content: Actor and comedian Sunil Grover is still known by his fans as Gutthi , the popular female character he portrayed on ‚Äò Comedy Nights with Kapil ‚Äô. ‚ÄúI loved playing all characters that I have played so far, but somehow I love becoming a woman on screen‚Ä¶ It is not easy to play a woman ‚Äì it requires a lot of practice. I think I feel very comfortable being a woman on screen and that is why people like me in that role,‚Äù said the ‚ÄòBharat‚Äô actor during an interview earlier. And to show his admiration and respect for women, the actor recently took to Instagram to support women all over the world. ‚ÄúNo one finds me woman enough to challenge, still I accept the B/W challenge,‚Äù he wrote, and posted a black and white picture of himself as Gutthi. Check it out!This trend has been going viral on social media, with multiple celebs joining in with the hashtag ‚Äò Challenge Accepted ‚Äô. Women have been posting their black and white photographs and nominating other women to post their own pictures and tag others. This aims to stand in solidarity and uplift other women worldwide.

Title: Coronavirus cases in India: Covid tally crosses 15 lakh; record 781 fatalities on Tuesday
Content:
For 2nd day, recoveries trump cases in Maharashtra

NEW DELHI: India‚Äôs Covid-19 caseload went past the 15-lakh mark on Tuesday, with the last 5 lakh cases having come in just 12 days, even as the country reported its second-biggest jump in infections and the highest death toll of 781 in a single day.After showing a dip on Monday, fresh cases again rose to 49,292 on Tuesday, the second-highest daily count after Sunday‚Äôs record of over 50,000, as per data collated from state governments. Deaths recorded during the day went past the previous single-day high of 757 on July 24.India‚Äôs coronavirus caseload is the third highest in the world after the US (44.3 lakh) and Brazil (24.4 lakh). Russia has the fourth largest count of cases at 8.2 lakh, as per the Worldometers.info website.For the first time in weeks, Maharashtra did not register the highest daily cases. It was dislodged by Andhra, which recorded 7,948 fresh cases.At 7,717, Maharashtra reported the second-highest count of daily cases.Fresh infections surged in the country although just three states ‚Äî Karnataka (5,536 new cases), Kerala (1,167) and Punjab (612) ‚Äî recorded their highest single-day jump in cases. Fresh cases in Maharashtra, which had dropped by nearly 1,500 to 7,924 on Monday, dipped further.However, several other big states reported fresh cases close to their highest yet, with Tamil Nadu detecting 6,972 infections, Uttar Pradesh recording 3,490, Bihar 2,480, Bengal 2,134, and Assam 1,348.With the highest jump in cases in the country, Andhra Pradesh‚Äôs cumulative caseload rose to 1,10,297. It now has the fifth largest caseload of cases, behind Maharashtra, TN, Delhi and Karnataka.For the second day in a row, daily discharges in Maharashtra were higher than daily additions, and discharges in Mumbai were nearly four times the daily addition. Even as the state and city registered a dip in cases, Covid fatalities reported on Tuesday went up to 282.

Title: Troops have disengaged in most ‚Äòlocalities‚Äô, claims China
Content:
India had in the last round of diplomatic talks on stressed the need for early and complete disengagement alon... Read More

NEW DELHI: Even as doubts remain about Chinese withdrawal along the LAC in Ladakh, with the process stuck in the Pangong Tso area, Beijing claimed on Tuesday that troops had disengaged in ‚Äúmost localities‚Äù and that the situation on the ground was easing.

India had in the last round of diplomatic talks on stressed the need for early and complete disengagement along the LAC and de-escalation in border areas. China had claimed ‚Äúpositive progress‚Äù in the talks. There has been vacation of friction zones and thinning in Galwan Valley . The spurs along Pangong lake and Depsang area remain contested.

‚ÄòFifth round of Commander-level talks planned‚Äô

As border troops have disengaged in most localities, the situation on the ground is de-escalating and the temperature is coming down,‚Äù Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin said in Beijing. There was no immediate reaction from MEA to the Chinese claim. An agency report from Beijing quoted government sources to say India had denied it.

The Chinese assertion came in response to a query from Global Times based on media reports and information received from ‚Äúsources‚Äù, as the journalist claimed. The journalist asked the spokesperson to confirm if it was true that disengagement had been completed in Galwan Valley, Hot Springs and Kongka Pass and that the only area left still was Pangong. The spokesperson said the two sides were currently preparing for the fifth round of commander-level talks to resolve outstanding issues on the ground.



In Video: China claims troops 'disengaged on most locations along LAC'

Title: Corbett tops in tiger count, Madhya Pradesh pips Karnataka
Content:
UP‚Äôs Sohagi Barwa gets a lone tiger

Jim Corbett national park in Uttarakhand has the most number of tigers in the country, with 231 of the 2,967 big cats counted for the ‚ÄòStatus of Tigers, Copredators & Prey in India‚Äô report released by Union forest and environment minister Prakash Javadekar on Tuesday.Corbett‚Äôs tiger count has been rising ‚Äî from 137 in 2006 to 174 in 2010 and 215 in 2014. ‚ÄúWe had expected the numbers to be over 250,‚Äù said director of the reserve, Rahul. It is followed by Nagarhole (127) and Bandipur (126), both in Karnataka, Bandhavgarh in MP (MP) and Kaziranga in Assam (104 each). Among states, MP topped the tiger estimation, with 526 (it had 308 last time), going past Karnataka (524 this time, 406 earlier).Uttarakhand remained on the third spot, with 442 tigers, up from 340 previously. The All India Tiger Estimation is undertaken every four years, the latest in 2018. This time, Corbett is the only reserve with more than 200 tigers and has the highest tiger density in India, 14. The count in Dudhwa Tiger Reserve has also gone up. ‚ÄúIt is a an increase from 58 to 82,‚Äù said Sanjay Kumar Pathak, field director of the reserve. Pilibhit reserve‚Äôs population is also up by two to 57. And what used to be a non-tiger zone in UP, Sohagi Barwa Wildlife Sanctuary, now has one tiger.But Mizoram‚Äôs Dampa reserve and Bengal‚Äôs Buxa lost the 6 tigers they had between them.

Title: Railways freight loading back at year-ago level
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: In a positive sign for the economy shrugging off a long period of lockdown and depressed growth due to the Covid-19 pandemic , the total freight loading on Monday was a little higher than the freight loaded a year ago.

The figures are good news for the national transporter, as passenger traffic remains low with people avoiding anything apart from essential travel and the need for business-related commuting also down. Railway board chairman V K Yadav told reporters that the total freight loading was 3.13 million tonnes (MT) on Monday as compared to 3.12 MTs on July 27, 2019.

Railways stare at 35k crore revenue loss from fares

Details available on Raildrishti , railway ministry portal on live data, show there was only 6.6% less loading of freight during this month as compared to July 2019. The improved freight movement indicates that supply chains are moving even though movement of foodgrains under the Centre‚Äôs welfare schemes may account for part of the traffic.

The impact of the pandemic will continue to be felt in terms of the railway‚Äôs revenues. The earning reported in the portal till Monday was Rs 7,668 crore, 12.2% less from freight earning in July 2019. The railways could be looking at a revenue loss of Rs 30,000 crore to Rs 35,000 crore from passenger segment against the projected earning of Rs 50,000 crore. The losses are expected given the impact due to Covid-19 but the renewed movement of freight holds out hope that the wheels of the economy are beginning to move again. Railway board chairman V K Yadav said the fact that freight loading has rebounded despite Covid is a good sign and railways is confident of increasing it by 50% during the current fiscal. ‚ÄúThis year we are looking at just 10-15% revenue from the passenger segment. Whatever revenue we lose from the passenger segment we will have to make it up by freight loading,‚Äù he added.



In Video: Indian Railways freight loading back at year-ago level

Title: ‚ÄòThok do saale ko‚Äô: Big B erupts at troll
Content: MUMBAI: Hitting out at an anonymous troll who had tweeted ‚ÄúI hope you die with this Covid‚Äù to Amitabh Bachchan , the actor late Monday wrote a blog post from his Covid ward in Nanavati Hospital in which he said his followers were ‚Äúincensed‚Äù and though he had not asked them to take any action against the troll, if he (Bachchan) survived Covid-19, he would. ‚ÄúAll I shall say to them,‚Äù he wrote, ‚Äúis thok do saale ko‚Äù.The 77-year-old actor and his son Abhishek have been in hospital since July 11 after they tested positive for the novel coronavirus . Referring to his ‚Äú90+ million followers‚Äù, Bachchan said if he survived, ‚ÄúI shall (ask them to take action)‚Ä¶ and let me tell you they are a force incensed.‚ÄùReferring to his ‚Äú90+ million followers‚Äù, Bachchan said, ‚Äúthey traverse the entire world from the west to the east from the north to the south.. and that extended family shall in the flash of an eye become ‚Äòextermination family‚Äô.‚ÄùAddressing the troll, Bachchan wrote, ‚ÄúHey Mr Anonymous.. you do not even write your father‚Äôs name.. because you do not know who fathered you.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúThere are only two things that could happen‚Ä¶ either I shall die or either I shall live.. if I die you won‚Äôt get to write your diatribe anymore, by weathering your remark on a celebrity name... pity... for, the reason of your writing to be noticed was, because you took a swipe at Amitabh Bachchan.. that shall no longer exist!‚Äù‚ÄúMay you burn in your own stew!‚Äù he wrote at the end of the blog after using Hindi adjectives such as ‚ÄúMahishasur‚Äù, ‚Äúcharitraheen‚Äù, ‚Äúbesharam‚Äù and ‚Äúbehaya‚Äù and even ‚Äúdestined to suffer like rakshasas‚Äù to describe the troll.Bachchan had on Sunday written about how isolation in a Covid ward takes a toll on mental health. Experts have spoken about the impact such isolation has on patients.

Title: Parliament building faces safety and space issues: Centre
Content:
The Indian Parliament (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Union government filed an affidavit before the Supreme Court on Tuesday saying the nearly 100-year-old Parliament building was showing signs of distress and faced many safety issues, including serious fire hazard, which necessitated construction of a modern building for the bicameral House under the Central Vista project, reports Dhananjay Mahapatra.

The Centre said construction of Parliament House was started in 1921 and completed in 1937. It is almost 100 years old. ‚ÄúOver the years, parliamentary activities have increased manifold. Therefore, it... is not able to meet the current requirements in terms of space, amenities and technology,‚Äù it said.

It said the Parliament building was designed to house the Imperial Legislative Council and not as a bicameral legislature ‚Äî Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha . ‚ÄúTwo floors were added in 1956. Fire safety is a major concern as the building is not designed according to present fire norms,‚Äù the government said in response to petitions challenging the Central Vista project.

Title: After Bihar Police files FIR in Sushant Singh Rajput's case, MP Subramanian Swamy says "no alternative to CBI probe"
Content:
If Bihar Police is serious about having a say in the investigation into the unnatural death of Sushant Singh Rajput‚Ä¶ https://t.co/oHFEnDxcuc ‚Äî Subramanian Swamy (@Swamy39) 1595937567000

Sushant Singh Rajput's father KK Singh filed a six-page long FIR at Rajiv Nagar police station in Patna alleging Rhea Chakraborty for abetting SSR to commit suicide.Meanwhile, Sushant's death case is currently being investigated by the Mumbai Police . Several big-wigs of Bollywood have recorded their statements with the police.Now, Rajya Sabha MP Subramanian Swamy took to Twitter to point out the possibility of CBI probe into SSR's unnatural death. He tweeted, "If Bihar Police is serious about having a say in the investigation into the unnatural death of Sushant Singh Rajput then there is no alternative to a CBI probe since Police of two States cannot separately investigate the same crime."Check out his tweet here:Earlier, he had written a letter to Prime Minister Narendra Modi demanding CBI probe into the matter. Title: Government panel opposes Kashmir 4G but LG ‚Äòsays he‚Äôs OK with it‚Äô
Content:
Lieutenant governor G C Murmu (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Centre faced an awkward situation in the Supreme Court on Tuesday as the high-powered committee (HPC) headed by the home secretary has rejected providing 4G internet services in Kashmir for the time being but media reports suggested that lieutenant governor G C Murmu favoured resumption of high-speed internet services.

With Jammu & Kashmir going to observe its first anniversary as a Union Territory on August 5, attorney general K K Venugopal and solicitor general Tushar Mehta wriggled out of the discomfiting situation by seeking a week‚Äôs time to present the correct picture before the SC.

A bench of Justices N V Ramana, R S Reddy and B R Gavai posted the matter for further hearing on August 5. The AG and the SG said the date (August 5) had some significance and requested that the hearing be held on some other day. The bench posted the matter for hearing on August 7.

Petitioner NGO ‚Äò Foundation for Media Professionals ‚Äô, through advocate Huzefa Ahmadi said though the HPC headed by the home secretary had declined making 4G internet services available in Kashmir for the time being, Murmu had told media organisations that the administration had no reservation if 4G services were provided in the UT. ‚ÄúOur only request is that the authorities should consider the issue magnanimously rather than on other considerations,‚Äù Ahmadi said.

The SC had ordered setting up of a HPC headed by the home secretary to periodically review the situation in the UT and determine whether high-speed internet services could be provided to people. The NGO had said that in the absence of internet services, students could not attend virtual classes during the pandemic when schools are closed and were lagging behind their peers in other states. It also said businessmen could not transact, doctors could not give online consultation to patients and people‚Äôs free speech was impeded because of lack of 4G services.

However, the Centre had said that faster internet services were being misused by elements inimical to peace who acted at the behest of a hostile neighbour to spread rumours and arouse passions of the public and disturb the atmosphere in the UT.



In Video: 4G internet in Kashmir: Government panel opposes, LG ‚Äòsays he‚Äôs OK with it‚Äô

Title: NSE platform to allow T-bill, state bond trade
Content:
Partha.Sinha@timesgroup.com

Mumbai: The NSE on Tuesday said investors can now purchase treasury bills ( T-bills ) and state government bonds through its platform. It already offers the option to invest in Gilts through its platform.

The move comes within a week of Sebi chairman Ajay Tyagi urging financial market participants to handhold those who have recently opened demat accounts to begin with investing in less-risky government securities before moving on to stocks.

‚ÄúIn line with equity trading, investors can now buy and sell T-bills and SDLs ( state development loans , or state government bonds) through NSE trading members. The dated government securities ( G-secs , also Gilts) are already offered in the capital market segment,‚Äù a release from the exchange said. ‚ÄúT-bills and SDLs are both part of the government securities group and have been widely accepted as a safer investment choice.‚Äù

Earlier in 2018, NSE had launched a platform for retail investors to bid in the government‚Äôs bond auctions through RBI‚Äôs ‚Äònon-competitive bidding‚Äô segment. NSE has now launched trading in G-secs, T-bills and state bonds to provide an alternate exit route to these investors who have subscribed through the primary market, the release said.

Title: Cos can‚Äôt fight new age war with culture fit for museum
Content:
By Prabir Jha

As organisations resort to digital quick fixes to keep their wheels churning, they must not declare success too early. While there surely will be a shift towards newer forms of working, we should be careful, or we will not see the wood for the trees.

Doing cosmetic changes will recarpet the old ways but will not help you truly move to a new world. As I keep reminding clients, don‚Äôt try and solve paediatric problems with geriatric solutions, even if they look youthful in their packaging.

Here are some fundamental reviews and changes if we want to enable our organisations to truly move towards being future ready:

* Composition of boards & CXO suites: In many cases, companies are stuck with leaders who were good and relevant in the years gone past. That, by default, is not good enough for the new times. There must be greater plurality in perspectives, functional and generational. Most boards still stay a preserve of convenience and years of relationship. The effectiveness of the boards to guide with more contemporary issues cannot be left out for politeness. Likewise, companies would do well to critique the quality of their leadership teams. Is there enough power to push forward? Is too much of past loyalty risking the future? Are there blockers or uninspiring leaders?

* Review your organisation‚Äôs architecture: As I listen to clients these days, I realise that many are slow to acknowledge that their structures are not quite aligned to their problems of today. And if they do, they struggle with changing it because of personalities that sit in boxes of such a structure. The world is amoebic today. How fluid is your organisation‚Äôs design? How do formal structures reshape to fight new wars, very much as militaries mobilise? What key gaps need new structures? What structures of the past now stand dilapidated or irrelevant and only harm cost and agility?

* Review your talent equation: Many companies will need to tweak, and possibly redefine, the way they serve their clients. While structures may need an obvious refresh, the talent staffing could have a new demand. Would it be possible to up-skill talent in the system? Or hire? Would we look at disruptive talent catchments? Would we take sharper risks and bets than in the past? What attributes beyond skills would we need more of, such that our talent is better attuned to win? These are all strategic calls and it may lead to be a big talent shake-up in companies, if they are serious about their future.

* Re-assess your organisational culture : It is good to be proud of one‚Äôs past, but dangerous to be blind to the limits of one‚Äôs legacy. As business models and customer-servicing shift, what is the strategic choice of culture for you? What will a ‚Äòdigital‚Äô culture really mean? I hear many companies struggle with a clear repudiation of aspects they were proud of thus far. They need help to know it is alright to get rid of a culture that has outlived its times. It never is easy to rewire a culture, but it is surely not prudent to fight a new-age war with a museum-worthy culture.

* Reinforce all your people systems afresh: A new world emerging from this huge crisis is a world of opportunity, if we dare to think afresh. It will in turn call for courage and reimagination of all HR systems and sub-systems, both to drive the change and then to reinforce them. Leadership essentials, talent definitions, structures & processes, rewards and recognition to sustain the culture shift ‚Äî all need a re-look. It is not a cost but an investment. At least an insurance premium. Bold HR thinking will need to lead and sustain all these strategic shifts. A huge shift must be from thinking HR the function to HR the agenda.

We are at a huge turning point. The way we turn will be how history judges us. The question though remains if we shall continue with an incremental and symbolic change, or truly have the courage to bite the tougher bullet? Hopefully, we will have more celebratory stories than obituaries to remember.

(The writer is the founder & CEO of Prabir Jha People Advisory )

Title: 91 new Covid-19 cases surface in Vadodara
Content:
The new cases were detected from 687 tests conducted in the city

Vadodara: With 91 new cases of Covid-19 being reported in the city and district since Monday evening, the total number of cases reported in the city since the beginning of the pandemic went up to 4,381. The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) confirmed three more deaths taking the total number of victims to 82 excluding those who died due to other health complications, but were Covid-19 positive.

The new cases were detected from 637 tests that were conducted in the city and district. In the city, the new cases were reported form Manjalpur, Vasna, Fatehpura, Fatehgunj, Chhani, Gorwa, Makarpura, Sangam, Tarsali, Waghodiya Road, Soma Talav, Harni Road, Akota, Ajwa Road, O P Road, Tandalja, Subhanpura, Gotri, Maneja and Karelibaug.

The worst affected area of the city was the south zone where 25 new cases were reported followed by the north and west zones where 23 and 12 cases came to light. Only eight persons tested positive in the east zone of the city.

In areas outside the VMC limits in Vadodara district, 23 new cases came to light. These were from the Padra, Karjan, Sokhda, Dashrath, Por, Itola and Koyali villages.

With 51 more patients being discharged from hospitals or home isolation on Tuesday, 3,346 persons have been discharged so far. This leaves 953 persons under hospitalization including 38 on ventilators or BiPAP machines and 143 on oxygen support. The condition of the remaining 953 persons is said to be stable.

Title: Vid nearing 13k, Covid peak @75k likely by mid-August
Content:
Nagpur: Even though Vidarbha has reported over 1,000 Covid cases, including 500 in the city alone, and increased number of casualties in the last two days in July, the region is nowhere near the peak of the outbreak. The reality is that we have only begun to see the surge, say experts.

Vidarbha‚Äôs total Covid-19 tally is nearing 13,000-mark with 555 cases reported in a single day on Monday. In view of the projected peak at 75,801 cases in Vidarbha, extreme caution and self-discipline is required now, say experts.

Based on the present situation, scientists have projected that Covid-19 outbreak would reach its peak by mid-August in many parts of the country. Data analysis of New Delhi, Mumbai, Pune, Nashik and the recent one in Akola also shows that Covid spread comes under control only after a certain peak.

The office of commissioner of health services, Mumbai, had in April projected the probable number of cases in a day and 10 days during peak of Covid-19. As per the projections, Vidarbha will have total 75,801 cases as the Covid-19 peak. (10 days preceding these numbers will be considered as the peak period). These include 18,902 cases from Nagpur district, of which 11,114 will be in city. At present, Nagpur district has less than 5,000 cases and Vidarbha is near 13,000, which suggests that the anticipated peak is still far away.

Interestingly, the same projection had stated that Akola Municipal Corporation will reach Covid-19 peak at 1,475 cases. Akola reached this number on July 20. Since then, the cases there are declining. On July 28, Akola Municipal Corporation area reported just three new cases and seven from the district.

A divisional health department senior official, who is member of National Task Force on Covid-19, said different areas in the country will reach peak at different times.
